result.execSummary:
The defendant Cameron C. Metheney was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. On one or more other charges, Cameron C. Metheney was found not guilty. These charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Cameron C. Metheney is presumed innocent of the not guilty charges.

  • Cameron C. Metheney was found guilty of Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

judgments.action: Found Not Guilty at Jury Trial

charges.dispoDesc: Found Not Guilty at Jury Trial

supervisions.notes:
Pay $250.00 fine plus costs. Fine and costs are paid in full.
--------------------------------

Provide biological specimen to state crime lab for DNA analysis, and pay DNA analysis surcharge.
--------------------------------
Pay DNA Surcharge in the amount of $200.00. Surcharge paid in full.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Cameron C. Metheney

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Cameron C. Metheney in court with attorney Peter Wilson.  Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
OFF THE RECORD, CLERK TAKES ATTENDANCE, SEATS FIRST 23 AND GIVES OATH TO POTENTIAL JURORS
BAILIFSS: LARRY MALSCH AND JAN CHAMBERS
Court in session @ 9:17 a.m. with first 23 jurors seated in the box. Court addresses jury, provides statement of the case, and has parties introduce themselves to the jury. 
9:20 a.m. - Voir Dire by the Court
9:26 a.m. - Voir Dire by ADA Leusink
9:41 a.m. - Voir Dire by Atty. Wilson
9:45 a.m. - Parties take their strikes. Court provides general information as to daily schedule, rules, lunches, etc..
9:56 a.m. - Final panel seated in jury box. Clerk swears panel. Remaining jurors excused. Panel excused for morning break. Court inquires whether there are any objections to the panel. Neither party objects. Parties have no other matters. Court inquires whether or not parties wish the Court to read instruction #50. Parties do not require Court to read said instruction.
Court in recess @ 9:59 a.m. for morning break.
10:16 a.m. - Court back in session with same appearances. Jury seated in jury box. Court reads short instruction to the jury as to duties and functions.
10:20 a.m. - Opening statement by ADA Leusink.
10:30 a.m. - Opening statement by Atty. Wilson
10:40 a.m. - Court takes short recess to address issue with Juror's problem with the case. Bailiff Jan Chambers makes a record as to statements by the juror in question. Parties agree that juror should be struck. Court addresses juror on the record who responds to questions by the Court.  Juror dismissed/excused, but is told to call in tomorrow morning.
10:44 a.m. - Jury seated in jury box. Court makes a record of juror dismissal
10:46 a.m. -  State calls Officer Kevin McNutt who is duly sworn and responds to direct exam of ADA Leusink.
11:09 a.m. - Cross exam by Atty. Wilson
11:24 a.m. - Redirect by ADA Leusink
Witness excused @ 11:25 a.m. Attorney Wilson has motion to be made outside the presence of the jury. Jury is excused. Atty. Wilson moves for directive verdict/dismissal based on grounds that not all elements of offenses have been proven beyond a reasonable doubt. Response by the Court. Atty. Wilson responds to Court's question and makes argument. Response by ADA Leusink. Court makes a record/finding and denies Atty. Wilson's motion for directed verdict/dismissal. 
11:29 a.m. - Court has colloquy with the defendant as to testifying. Defendant responds to Court's questions. Court makes a finding that the defendant is knowingly and intelligently making the decision to testify.
11:32 a.m. - Jury seated in jury box. Attorney Wilson calls Cameron C. Metheney who is duly sworn and responds to direct exam. 
11:52 a.m. - Cross exam by ADA Leusink
12:01 p.m. - Witness excused. Defense rests.
Court in recess for lunch until 1:30 p.m.
1:25 p.m. - Court back in session with jury seated in jury box. State calls rebuttal witness, Deputy Michael Lauderdale who is duly sworn and responds to direct exam of ADA Leusink. No cross. Witness excused.
1:27 p.m. - State recalls Officer McNutt who remains under oath and responds to direct exam of ADA Leusink. No cross. Witness excused.
1:30 p.m. - Record is closed. Court excuses jury to allow parties to discuss jury instructions and verdict forms.
1:31 p.m. - Parties discuss jury instructions outside the presence of the jury. Defense objects to instruction 1765 and requests additional language as noted in comments of instruction. Discussion. Additional objection by Atty. Wilson as to the specific language inserted into instruction by the State. Discussion. Parties agree on final instructions/closing arguments. Court makes a record of agreed upon instructions by number. No objection to the form of verdicts.
1:51 p.m. - Jury seated in jury box. Court reads panel jury instructions
2:07 p.m. - Closing argument by ADA Leusink
2:27 p.m. - Closing argument by Atty. Wilson
2:35 p.m. - Rebuttal argument by ADA Leusink
2:39 p.m. - Court reads final instructions to the Jury. Clerk swears Bailiffs. Jury excused for deliberations.
2:42 p.m. - Parties have no objection to the instructions as read. Court in recess until there is a question or a verdict.
4:23 p.m. - Court back in session with same appearances. Jury has reached a verdict. Bailiff hands verdicts to the Court. Court reads the verdicts.
Jury finds the Defendant Not Guilty Resisting
Jury finds the Defendant Guilty Disorderly Conduct
Parties do not wish the jury polled. Court reads final instruction, and discharges jury panel.
State moves for Judgment on the verdicts. Atty. Wilson does the same.  Court dismisses resisting charge and enters judgment of conviction on the DC charge.
Parties are ready to proceed to sentencing. 
State recommends a $250.00 fine plus costs and no jail time. Response by Atty. Wilson that they have no objection to recommendation by the State.

Court orders $250.00 fine plus costs.
DNA Sample/Surcharge

Court in recess @ 4:30 p.m.

Defendant Cameron C. Metheney in court with attorney Andrew Mishlove for Peter Wilson.  Matthew R. Leusink appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Parties confirmed for trial. Trial will be one (1) day and will begin on Thursday, August 25th. Minutes filed.

Final pre-trial on August 23, 2016 at 10:00 am.
Jury trial - 12 person on August 25, 2016 at 09:00 am.

Attorney Peter Wilson appeared.  Daniel A. Necci appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Motion deadline 07-18-16. Bond remains.  Minutes filed.  Final pre-trial scheduled for August 23, 2016 at 10:00 am.  Jury trial - 12 person scheduled for August 25, 2016 at 09:00 am.

Attorney Peter Wilson appeared.  Matthew W. Surridge appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Not guilty plea entered. Bond Remains. Minutes filed.  Status conference scheduled for March 18, 2016 at 08:30 am.
Plaintiff's Demand and Motion for Discovery and Inspection.  Notice of Motion and Motion for Establishment of Discovery Deadlines.
Defendant Cameron Metheney not present. Attorney Pete Wilson appeared. Diane Donohoo appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Minutes filed.
Signed bond filed with the court.

Defendant shall not possess or consume alcohol.  Defendant is to be booked and printed within twenty-four (24) hours.  Defendant will not in any way contact or attempt to contact any victim(s) listed and will avoid their residence/place of employment or any place they are located and will avoid causing any other person, other than defendant's attorney, from doing so on defendant's behalf.  The term "no contact" is hereby defined as through the mail, by telephone, by way of electronic device, in person, or through a third party.  VICTIM(S)/RESIDENCE(S): NO CONTACT WITH THE SUGAR SHACK.  Defendant shall personally ensure that payments are made under any Order for Income Withholding if the Court appoints an attorney for the defendant.
